item.title: Rollout of ‘miracle’ HIV prevention drug is threatened by Trump cuts to global AIDS relief program - statnews.com
item.description:
The Trump administration’s enormous cuts to a global AIDS relief program threaten to upend the planned rollout of a groundbreaking HIV prevention drug that was expected to save countless lives. 

The medicine, lenacapavir, made by Gilead Sciences, has caused a stir because clinical trial data showed a single set of injections every six months could provide virtually complete protection against infection, a form of prevention known as pre-exposure prophylaxis, or (PrEP). The drug, which is under regulatory review, has raised hopes that the deadly infectious disease can be mitigated around the globe. Early data for an even newer formulation suggest it might need to be given only once a year. “This is magical,” UNAIDS chief Winnie Byanyima declared last year. 

The President’s Emergency Plan for AIDS Relief, or PEPFAR, has been poised to play the leading role in making lenacapavir available, given its experience distributing HIV prevention drugs around most of the world.  

Last December, PEPFAR and The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria crafted an arrangement to cover dosing for 2 million people over three years in dozens of low and middle-income countries. This closely followed a voluntary licensing deal that Gilead Sciences reached with six companies to make low-cost, generic versions.

The effort is widely seen as a key step in a widely shared goal to eradicate HIV and AIDS by 2030. For this reason, global health advocates warn that, by threatening to pull PEPFAR funding, the U.S. could squander a pivotal moment in a pandemic that still infects 1 million new people every year. For the first time, a vaccine-esque intervention is available, they say, if people can actually get the medication. 

“It’s tragic because it’s coming at the worst possible moment,” said Mitchell Warren, who heads the AIDS Vaccine Advocacy Coalition, or AVAC, a nonprofit that receives backing from PEPFAR and recently filed a lawsuit in hopes of preventing the Trump administration from proceeding with global funding cuts. “In 44 years of this epidemic, we’ve never had an opportunity like lenacapavir.”

Indeed, PEPFAR plays a crucial role in combating HIV around the world. The U.S. agency is responsible for providing approximately 90% of the HIV prevention efforts globally, including services, according to Jirair Ratevosian, an associate research scientist at Yale, who is a former acting chief of staff at PEPFAR and also a former executive director of corporate social responsibility at Gilead.

The Trump Administration, however, recently halted much of PEPFAR’s funding as part of a wider — and highly controversial — move to dismantle the U.S. Agency for International Development, or USAID. After public outcry, though, Secretary of State Marco Rubio signed a waiver in January to keep parts of PEPFAR funded for 90 days. The State Department operates PEPFAR.

Last week, meanwhile, a one-year congressional authorization for PEPFAR expired, making its future uncertain, even though Congress appropriated funding through the end of September by way of a continuing resolution that recently passed. For the moment, nothing is likely to get decided about PEPFAR’s future until the Trump administration completes its review by April 20.

“Right now, no prevention is happening. I’m hoping prevention isn’t seen as optional, but as a historic opportunity to create prevention tools people want and need,” said Ratevosian. “But if PEPFAR’s posture is curtailed and its budget is cut in any significant way after the foreign aid review, I don’t see how PEPFAR could prioritize executing on distributing lenacapavir.”

STAT asked the State Department for comment. A Gilead spokesperson said: “We are monitoring current developments, and support efforts to continue to prioritize access to vital tools such as HIV prevention medications so together, we can achieve the global goal of ending the HIV epidemic.”

To be sure, lenacapavir is not the only worry among advocates and health policy experts. PEPFAR disburses $6 billion to $7 billion each year for antiretroviral drugs, outreach workers, educational and other services. Overall, the program is estimated to have saved 26 million lives since its inception in 2003, but its sudden and chaotic defunding jeopardizes millions of lives across Africa and the Caribbean.

It is not surprising that the Gilead drug is garnering considerable attention. Unlike pills for preventing HIV, a highly effective, long-acting injectable offers the promise of broader protection by easing compliance. To date, the only other such injectable is sold by ViiV Healthcare, although it must be administered every two months, compared with twice a year.

After Gilead released its trial data last year, Francois Venter, who runs an infectious disease research clinic at University of the Witwatersrand in Johannesburg, said the results became the center of instant conversation. In some sub-Saharan countries, the drug may have a slower impact, because health infrastructure is weaker. But in South Africa, he said, it could “break the back of the epidemic.”

Nombeko Mpongo, a patient advocate and community liaison in Cape Town who helped design the study, agreed. She contracted HIV after she was raped in 1997, when the virus was still a death sentence spreading widely through South Africa, and saw lenacapavir as the kind of tool that could protect her children and grandchildren. She spent months educating schools and NGOs about it. Now, though, “we don’t even know when and how we’re going to get it,” she said. “It’s a disaster.”

Anticipation grew still higher last month when Gilead Sciences released fresh data showing that a new formulation of its drug could provide virtually complete protection against infection with just a single administration every year — and make an even greater contribution to ending the HIV epidemic. 

The collaboration between PEPFAR and the Global Fund — which would also involve the Children’s Investment Fund Foundation and the Gates Foundation — was seen as a way to fulfill such promise. The stated goal is to get doses distributed as widely as possible and show generic manufacturers a significant market exists so they are encouraged to scale quickly and thus lower costs.

It stirred excitement among global health advocates. Oral PrEP and ViiV’s medicine were slow to reach much of the world, in part because resources weren’t deployed to scale and broadly distribute them, and PrEP usage remains well below UN targets.  The agreement’s goal was to “ensure that the world doesn’t squander this opportunity as it did each of the last PrEP launches over the last 15 years,” said Warren, whose group consulted on the deal. Meanwhile, there is confusion about how widely work has been able to resume, given the sudden lack of resources. And the Rubio waiver specifically called for PEPFAR to only fund prevention for pregnant and breastfeeding women, leaving out vulnerable populations such as adolescent girls and young men who have sex with men. 

A PEPFAR official, who spoke on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to discuss the situation, said they assume the administration will adopt a similar policy going forward. That could permit access to the drug in wealthy nations, but “you essentially have no ability to implement lenacapavir” where the bulk of infections occur, according to Chris Beyrer, Director of the Duke Global Health Institute.

Nonetheless, The Global Fund is hoping to find a way to proceed. Peter Sands, who heads the public-private partnership last month told Bhekisisa Centre for Health Journalism, a nonprofit media group based in South Africa, that “we are still maintaining our ambition on lenacapavir” even if the rollout is on a smaller scale. “We cannot afford to miss such a game-changing opportunity,” he said.

To what extent The Global Fund can make good on its ambition is unclear. The organization is in the midst of trying to raise $18 billion to continue its mission for the next three years. A big unknown, at least for the moment, is whether donors will provide enough money to compensate for the PEPFAR cuts. Other countries have also cut their foreign assistance budgets, adding to the uncertainty. A spokeswoman for The Global Fund declined to comment.

In hope of moving HIV prevention forward, UNAIDS’ Byanyima late last month argued that ensuring lenacapavir is available is a “deal not to be missed.” How so? She noted the drug is an American innovation that could yield profits for Gilead if it licenses the medicine as planned. In doing so, this would not only create jobs for Americans, but save millions of lives in poor countries.

She maintained that this could only happen, though, if the Trump administration sees that this is, in effect, a good deal. “It is an amazing deal. President Trump likes to cut deals,” Byanyima said at a media briefing in Geneva. “It could be President Trump, another Republican president, who leads the prevention revolution towards the end of AIDS.”

Byanyima did note U.S. funding accounted for about 45% of the core UNAIDS budget last year and it was unlikely other donors could fill that vacuum, especially since European donors have already indicated they would cut back on their support as they redirect funds toward defense. She warned that, unless HIV efforts are restored, another 6.3 million deaths could occur as 2,000 people a day become infected.

“People now have to make unpopular choices, and everyone needs to reassess priorities, such as whether the Gilead drug is still a priority,” said Alan Whiteside, an AIDS researcher and a professor emeritus at the University of KwaZulu-Natal in South Africa, who is now a fellow at the Balsillie School of International Affairs in Canada. “But if PEPFAR is gutted, PEPFAR cannot make good on its mission.”

John Nkengasong, who led PEPFAR from 2022 until Trump’s inauguration and had been the first director of the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention, put it this way: lenacapavir is “a unique opportunity, a unique opportunity to turn the tide in the fight against HIV/AIDS… The science has given us the tools to fight HIV, which we cannot relent. We cannot give up at the last mile.”

The story has been updated with a comment from Gilead Sciences.
item.author: statnews.com

item.title: A yoga instructor recommends practicing this pose if your lower back hurts at the end of the day - Fit&Well
item.description:
Lower back pain is a global epidemic with 619 million people suffering from this condition worldwide, according to an article published in The Lancet Rheumatology journal. And by 2050, this number is set to reach 843 million.

If spending prolonged periods in one position has left you feeling stiff and achy, yoga instructor Nicole Wood, a master trainer at YogaSix, says one move can help: standing forward fold.

"There are many poses that offer relief for low back pain," Wood explains. "Personally, I prefer a standing forward fold because that is what feels best in my body.

“I feel that a forward fold offers a complete reset of my spine, and also helps to relax my neck and shoulders.

“After a long day of sitting, and working at my desk, when I enter a forward fold, I feel relief through my backside body. I can feel the space between my vertebrae become more open."

How to do the movement

Wood recommends completing three to five repetitions of standing forward fold and holding the stretch for 30 seconds. The instructor advises doing the move when you wake up, after you’ve finished work, and before bed.

"You can do this every day of the week," Wood explains. "There is no rule limiting how many forward folds one does, just be mindful with movement and breath."

Start your week with achievable workout ideas, health tips and wellbeing advice in your inbox.

Repetitions: 3-5 Time: 30 seconds

  • Stand in a mountain pose with your feet hip-width apart, arms by your side and your core engaged. Ground down through your feet to lengthen your spine.
  • Inhale and raise your arms overhead.
  • Exhale, fold forward by hinging at the hips. Maintain a small bend your knees and lead the movement with your chest.
  • Relax your hands and head towards the ground.
  • Draw your navel in and up and engage your quads (front thigh muscles) and hip flexors (at the top of your legs).
  • Move deeper into the stretch with every breath. Inhale, find length in your spine, exhale and fold deeper.
  • Modifications: If your hands don’t reach the ground, place your hands on yoga blocks, or on your shins or hips. You may wish to bend your knees and bring your hands to your thighs.

The benefits of doing standing forward fold

Standing forward fold, or Uttanasana as it’s known in Sanskrit, is one of the best yoga poses for beginners for flexibility. But that’s not the only benefit.

"Anytime you are folding forward in a yoga pose, there is a calming effect on the nervous system," Wood explains.

"A standing forward fold also strengthens the thighs and knees, while stretching the

hamstrings, calves, hips, glutes, shoulders, and soles of feet.

"Folding forward also helps improve digestion. When the belly is folding over the thighs there

is gentle stimulation to the digestive system."

Wood says forward fold can also help the spine stay strong and supple, supporting better posture.
item.author: Fit&Well
